props.header: An international leader in the exploration of ethics, the Emory Center for Ethics is dedicated to exploring how ethical issues underlie the decisions that shape our minds, lives, and society.
props.text: Scholars from across the university gather at the Center for Ethics to collaborate and study. Scholarship, conversation, and understanding are promoted through public programs, partnerships, and consultations with private and public community organizations. Emory’s renowned ethicists are committed to asking tough questions and developing strategies that enable individuals and organizations to put ethics into practice.
props.media_alt: People with umbrellas walk on streets.

props.text: Art can be a powerful instrument for personal transformation because it not only functions as an invitation to explore the meaning of the art itself and the identity of the artist who created it, but art also invites us to explore who we are and what we believe. Because of this invitation, we may discover new modalities for our own existence, we may be challenged to interrogate some of our own beliefs, and ultimately we may be confronted with new ideas that broaden our own perspectives.

props.title: In 2O36, Graduate Studies in Ethics are Available to All
props.body:
As we’ve seen throughout the COVID-19 pandemic, the study of social and ethical challenges facing medicine and life sciences is continually evolving. Professionals and students dive deep into these challenges with rigorous interdisciplinary study in the Master of Arts in Bioethics program.

Our graduates help advance the national conversation on important issues influencing public policy, scholarship, practice, and education in these fields. Funding for scholarships allows us to recruit the best and the brightest, while leveling the playing field for students to pursue careers aligned with their passions and talents without worrying about overwhelming debt. The successful future for health and the life sciences depend on our ability to financially support scholars learning how to address ongoing and emerging social and ethical challenges in healthcare.
props.media_text: The future of health care and the life sciences depend on our ability to financially support scholars learning how to address ongoing and emerging social and ethical challenges in these areas.

props.title: Experiential Learning Trains the Ethical Leaders of the Future
props.body:
The need for ethical servant leaders has never been greater. The Center's D. Abbott Turner Program in Ethics and Servant Leadership (EASL) is shaping future community leaders with hands-on training and a guided, purposeful opportunity for individual reflection. Students live out ethical leadership in this sought-after summer internship program that benefits local nonprofits. The expertise they gain in real-world situations has lasting effects on Emory and wider society.

Increasing scholarship support will allow students from all backgrounds to participate in this important program regardless of financial situation, while providing Atlanta’s community organizations with skilled and talented support to further their missions.

props.title: Advancing Humanity with Ethical AI
props.body:
The remarkable advances in artificial intelligence (AI) promise unprecedented advantages—in commerce, medicine, and our everyday lives. Yet, the development of AI is fraught with complex challenges. Ethics is intrinsic to AI and the Center for Ethics is on the frontline, expertly guiding scholars, researchers, professionals, and entrepreneurs in ways that AI applications will promote human flourishing, eliminate bias, manage ambiguity, and employ ethical decision-making.

The Center for Ethics is prepared to advance the creation of review boards for far-reaching AI decisions, while also providing ethics training for those working in machine learning at research institutions, private companies, and government oversight agencies.

A generous gift to 2O36 will allow us to create an Endowed Program Leader in AI and Ethics to ensure we bring ethics to bear when developing, funding, implementing, and responding to AI in different settings.
props.media_alt: Students lay on ground in circle.
props.media_text: Funding from 2O36 will allow us to expand these programs,addressing growing student demand, both at Emory and peer institutions in metro Atlanta.

items.title: Cultivating the Ethics and the Arts Program
items.description:
Emory University’s Center for Ethics is experienced in convening and facilitating difficult conversations across many subjects and for diverse communities. Art - whether it is film, theater, or the visual arts - has proven to be a unique and powerful catalyst that prompts us to confront ethical challenges. Our aim is to engage in ethical dialogue in ways that are both supportive of peoples’ differences and challenging to their preconceptions.

The Center’s Ethics and the Arts Program continues to bring superlative interactive programs to the Emory and Atlanta communities. Through the arts, we create opportunities for disparate communities, partner organizations, students, artists, scholars, and the public to come together for meaningful and respectful dialogue that results in an action plan for collective social change.

A generous gift to 2O36 will allow us to create an Endowed Program Leader in Arts and Ethics to ensure the Center for Ethics remains the Emory pacesetter in guided conversations and programming that lead to ethical literacy and social justice.

items.title: Recruit and Retain Top Talent in Bioethics
items.description:
Comprehensive, cross-disciplinary training for clinicians leads to better patient outcomes. Thus, we have a duty to educate physicians and health care workers in ethical issues around science, health care systems, and clinical care. This is a key commitment of the Center for Ethics—our curriculum encompasses the health sciences, scholarship and research in clinical ethics, public health ethics, health policy, and neuroethics.

The pandemic has created unprecedented demand for these programs and with that demand comes increased faculty need. Increased funding through 2036 will allow the center to expand the faculty through an Endowed Bioethics Program Leader who will support outreach to students and the wider healthcare community, provide greater access to this crucial program, and allow us to increase the scope of our most prominent bioethics programs.

items.title: Working Toward an Ethical Community
items.description:
Community outreach is a cornerstone of Emory’s commitment to society, and it helps students, professionals, and the public confront and understand ethical issues in health, technology, the arts, the environment, and the life sciences. The Center for Ethics fosters public discussion and experiential learning through community engagement activities and outreach.

In our programs, students and community members engage with ongoing and emerging issues in food studies, health care, social justice, the arts, and more. In and out of classrooms, they’re free to address complex ethical and social challenges in civil discussion and debate that elevates public discourse and increases mutual understanding. Funding would ensure the continuation and expansion of these in-demand signature programs, both at Emory and in the Atlanta area. The hope is that they lead to deeper civic understanding and more civil discourse in a world that so desperately needs them.
